text: and today we are launching the Amazon
API Gateway that makes it really simple
to put apis on your
software it's a fully managed service
you just drop you just assign um a front
door you define what the API is you're
connected to a back end you know the
back end can be an easy two instance but
it can also just be lot
function yeah so you may build your
mobile application and you may may build
your mobile backend the mobile backend
has these apis and behind it just C
these Lambda functions that get executed
it's fully managed environment and
indeed you can RN these backend
applications as either E2 instance or
Lambda
functions and there is no minimum fee or
startup cost so this allows you to
integrate apis into all of the software
that you've built I'd like to to invite
Dr Matt Wood back on stage to walk you
through how this really
[Music]
works thank you verer so the Amazon API
Gateway is an incredibly simple way to
create robust scalable and secure rest
apis literally in minutes and if you're
not familiar what are the components of
a rest API there's really just three
components the first is a series of
resources these resources in the
abstract sense are the things of your
application so if you're building a real
estate application this would be the
houses and the properties and the prices
of those properties if you're building
an auction application these would be
the bids and the items that were
available for auction and how rest apis
work is that you assign methods against
those resources and access them at the
end of a URL so you can assign htttp
requests methods like gets and posts and
puts that you're used to using send
those to a URL and interact with the
resources inside your application and
what you respond with is a
representation of your resource so this
representation may be HTML for a web
application but it could be XML or Json
or any other kind of interchange format
that you have and these three components
form the backbone of the API uh Gateway
and you go about creating it in just
three really easy ways the first thing
you need to do is you want to be able to
create your resources and this is as
simple as typing in a name and typing in
the endpoint the URL endpoint that you
want to be able to access that uh
resource on then you want to assign and
attach your HTTP methods so you can just
assign gets and puts and posts and these
usually map to the kind of crud create
retrieve update and delete operations
that are familiar to many database users
and at the ends of those methods you can
assign any publicly accessible endpoint
so you can proxy into an application
which is running on ec2 you can proxy to
any other application running on the
Internet or you can use no servers
whatsoever and run Lambda applica Lambda
uh Cloud functions in response to API
calls and you just go through and select
the one you want it's as easy as
clicking in the
console finally you want to be able to
take your resources and the methods that
you've just defined and you want to be
able to deploy those so that you can
access them and the API Gateway supports
not just one version of an application
but multiple versions of the application
and not just one environment stage but
multiple and arbitrary uh environment
stages for your API so you can choose
whether you want to deploy a particular
version in a particular environment just
with a few clicks or ironically through
the API Gateway API so you can choose to
run in Alpha Beta production anything
that you want then you just Define and
what you get at the end of that is an
invocation endpoint and this is where
you file your url requests to with all
that information to interact with your
resources and get back that those
representations and this is the
architecture that you're really aiming
to build up where you have your
front-end applications mobile
applications websites you have other
backend applications services that are
either coming from third parties or you
own yourself connecting directly to the
API Gateway and that API Gateway is
receiving and managing all the requests
for the API and sending them on either
to ec2 endpoints to Lambda functions
that you configure or to any other
publicly accessible endpoint but it
doesn't stop there the API Gateway has a
lot of magic and a lot of smarts built
into it to help you manage manage and
build these applications at scale so one
of those features is we provide a
Gateway cache so if you cach the
response to an API call you don't have
to go back to your infrastructure to get
it again if it hasn't changed you can
just hit the cache and send the request
directly out that makes it much easier
to manage the scale of your backend
applications that's built directly into
the gateway and we also provide robust
and deep Cloud watch metrics so you can
really get a good sense of what's
Happening inside your API and who's
doing what to your resources so there's
a huge amount of smarts for creating
robust scalable and secure apis we add
versioning so you can manage multiple
and arbitary versions of your
application API we add metering and
throttling so you can see who's doing
what and get in-depth logs and then you
can throttle against that usage so you
can keep the pressure off the back end
of your system by throttling the the
usage we had caching which we've already
talked about we also support signing and
authorization with AWS Sig V4 and we'll
even automatic generate the SDK for you
for JavaScript IOS and Android so you
can take your definition and instantly
build it into your application and those
sdks respect throttling and will back
off and retry automatically so that's a
high level view of the Amazon API
Gateway uh I'd love you for you to give
it a try and I can't wait to see what
you'll build I'll hand it back over to
Vera thank
[Music]
[Applause]
you I cannot emphasize enough of what a
game changer the API Gateway is going to
be
